job_title: Head of Service in Oldham, England
pros: Puts people at the heart of what it does Social purpose Opportunities to learn, develop and grow
cons: Challenging sector to work in, with focus on customers and property management

review_title: Not what it used to be
pros: Wage. Work there if you need a decent wage just don’t expect a bonus. Colleagues who experience the same issues will understand and support you more than management or HR will. On site car parking.
cons: Delegation of work given staff at the bottom of the chain that should be completed by higher management but they refuse to learn or adapt to their role or responsibilities. No flexibility in hours for some teams. ‘Who you know not what you know’ culture when it comes to career progression - people with 10+ years of experience of working in housing or their area of knowledge being overlooked for promotions so that the boss’ friends get the job. Misogyny and racism is rife - don’t let the ‘diverse culture’ fool you, some people try their hardest to be equal, when others expect you to ‘put up, shut up and look pretty’ air quotes because this was said to me by a head of service. Too much of a work load in certain departments but not enough staff to bear it. You’re only ever treated as a number, don’t expect anyone to care about you or your well-being. The vision Arthur Guinness once had of supplying affordable homes to the most destitute and in need is slipping for the business wanting to make profit by selling poor quality flats for £600k in built up areas but no one seems to want to put that money into helping residents who consistently report issues with their homes that are crumbling.

job_title: Tenancy Enforcement Officer in Havant, England
pros: There are only three. 1) The wage - Higher than comparable jobs in the region. 2) Instant hot water and cooled water tap in the kitchen. 3) Leave is always approved even when 99% of the team is already off because non of the managers speak to each other.
cons: Too many to list but to name a few: 1) Incompetent management - over 6 different manager changes for 1 team in the space of 12 months. Forced out good managers and brought in incompetent managers who have zero managerial capabilities and inability to understand the basics of ASB. 2) More focus on mandatory training for asbestos than training on current practises and improvement sharing. 3) Lack of understanding what challenges staff are facing even when brought to their attention they seem to ignore it.

job_title: IT Helpdesk Analyst in Oldham, England
pros: Only pros were that of your colleagues in created a barrier from the impossible expectations making the difficult days good. The pay was okay (as long as you never had to contact HR)
cons: The constant stress and pressure coming from management with unrealistic targets and lack of foresight. The bottom customer facing staff had to endure a barrage of poor deployment of projects that are forced out with little to no communication causing stress and breaking points on those staff, many went off sick and the team I was in never saw a full staffing always left short and exhausted while expecting goals to be met. The management are selfish and broken. I’ve witnessed managers take ideas, suggestions and pass them off as their own while soaking up the praises of others. While they appear open and friendly that is until you approach with issues and watch your concerns get swept aside. I’ve seen managers take on work, decide not to delegate and blame their team for failings that are not theirs but the managers. They went through a 5 1/2 year restructuring creating instability and at the end of it still had no idea what they were trying to deliver while using it to get rid of people that had voiced concerns in procedures All in all the bottom staff are stretched thin with no help or patience to train, and will be let go if struggling. A toxic environment where only the management succeeds. There are too many cons.

pros: They pay well for the job title
cons: Constant restructuring and refuse to acknowledge feedback from those who do the job and who trialed the changes Workload has gradually become unmanageable - keep adding responsibilities without increase in salary Not valued - when plans pointed out they won’t work staff were told ‘they’re aware they’ll lose staff’ and then they genuinely questioned why everyone is giving notice

review_title: The worst Management I have every experienced
pros: Good basic Good holiday allowance Quite flexible with working and hybrid working
cons: Commission structure is awful - if you do well they will keep increasing your target until you cannot possibly reach it, and they do not release properties for sale until halfway through the quarter you are already on a hiding to nothing. Management could not care less about staff in any department Many of the staff are only there for the high salaries so do not try to work hard Customers service is non existent and does not seem important at all to Guinness. The systems are constantly changing and not for the better. Long winded, full of bugs and no-one really knows what they are doing. Lots of promises made but none kept Do not expect a voice as you will not be listened to If you speak up then you will be blacklisted. Don't give them any ideas, they will take them, use them, but will not give you any credit. No career progression opportunities No stability of work - but that is normal in housing They take diversity and inclusion too far and to the detriment of others. If you are discriminated against they will not support you unless it suits them.

pros: Holidays , The pay is ok , you can get better
cons: The management are bullies and tell lies, HR are conpleat robots , Great place to work , In your dreams. Zero stars is what you should get.

pros: Like dealing with the home occupiers
cons: Not a very nice place to work, lot of toxicity between staff at all levels.

pros: The staff on the front line
cons: Bully outdated management. Like being back in the early 90s - business change function that doesn’t want to change. Do as I say or otherwise…..

review_title: Good place to work with excellent supportive colleagues
pros: Some amazing staff who go the extra mile. Fabulous colleagues, lovely office, feel like you’re making a difference. Pay is good, bonus scheme an incentive.
cons: Customer contact team not supported with difficult calls. Some colleagues lazy and needlessly obstructive. Others found atmosphere cliquey. HR not always supportive when facing difficult management issues.

pros: Salary and benefits are good.
cons: Low morale sometimes amongst the staff

pros: A few nice people to work with, some nice planners
cons: Horrible managers will step all over you to get to the top

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Oldham, England
pros: Local place to work from
cons: Stressful customers have no respect

pros: Great holiday entitlement and benefits
cons: Nothing, none cons to report

review_title: It once was great now lacks direction
job_title: Customer Accounts Advisor in Oldham, England
pros: Great team who want to make a difference. A degree of flexible working.
cons: Micromanagement Lack of managerial direction Unwanted pressure to staff

pros: Core hours, staff, big, company, relaxed
cons: Dead end job Rubbish wage

pros: Great office space in Oldham and London
cons: Dispersed locations made it a bit disconnected

job_title: Customer Accounts Advisor in Oldham, England
pros: Great team, good vibe, made some good friends. Good pay & benefits Looked after us during covid
cons: lots of changes happening to teams and ways of working

pros: Very nice colleagues, good property portfolio
cons: Lack of vision of vision

job_title: Customer Service Agent in Oldham, England
pros: Good pay compared to other housing association.
cons: Call center job so if uou like phone then go for it.

job_title: Customer Service Advisor in Oldham, England
pros: I think Guinness are fair and treat staff relatively well
cons: Limited support handling difficult customers

pros: Some good jobs in the main locations of Oldham or London, otherwise your career choices are limited. Hybrid working.
cons: Another round of redundancies. When will this company learn to listen to people who do the jobs and not Consultancy Firms? The Consultant is the only one to profit from this type of slash and burn exercise. In the long run Guinness will be the loser. Not forgetting of course the employees who’ve had their lives ruined.

job_title: Multi Skilled Technician in Milton Keynes, England
pros:
They pay relatively well, plenty of holiday and sick pay.
Very easy, non taxing work
cons:
If you’re not part of the supervisory/managerial hierarchy then you’ve zero chance of progression.

Not what you know it’s who you know.

Promotion jobs not advertised to engineers and just given to people not suitable for the role and who are related to higher management

Hiring policy for skilled engineers is lacking. No technical questions asked at interview stage for example.

Lack of competency at supervisor/managerial level. Sense of doing very little and, in some cases, stealing a living.

Tried to get new London contract up and running in 2021 and to call it a debacle would be an understatement

Since COVID the office staff have been able to work from home. Somehow, that means that they are even harder to get hold of!

pros: service users, training, work colleagues
cons: Short staffed, expected to do overtime, no travel time, communication

review_title: Used to be a great place to work
job_title: Customer Service Advisor in Oldham, England
pros: Colleagues all have the same goals and visions, competitive salary, good location, helping other people. Understanding and supportive line managers, family environment
cons: Under staffed, under resourced, senior managers rarely come to the office, treated like a number by the senior management, rarely mentioned or praised.

pros: None , they are not a good company to work for
cons:
Disorganised & the atmosphere was not good . Management are poor , lots of people left around the same time as me due to more cost cutting & expecting us to take on more & more tasks . 
The amount of complaints was a problem but we could do nothing , the job was very stressful at the end .

job_title: Office Administration Assistant in Manchester, England
pros:
Good company to work for with great benefits 
Lots of opportunities to move around departments
cons: Too many restructures, no job is safe

job_title: Scheme Manager in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England
pros: Regular hours, work to own schedule .
cons: Poor pay, to may areas to cover.

job_title: Customer Liaison Officer in Manchester, England
pros: Ok place to work most of the time
cons: Internal politics not good, weak HR dept

pros: good colleagues, good pay and nice work environment
cons: there aren't many cons except the lack of communication sometimes

pros: Zero pros to working for Guinness
cons: Management are awful, absolutely no forward thinking and everything is a struggle. Too many chiefs and shocking staff retention.

pros: Good salary as it’s a national provider.
cons: Company has a lack of understanding of the roles within it and just cares about KPI’s.

pros:
They do what they can to help you if you suffer with mental health issues

Generous holidays 

Good hours

Good money
cons: Not enough time with my team, due to working from home. Not Guinness fault

review_title: Can be great, but can be toxic.
pros:
Some amazing people work here, knowledgeable, hard working, caring etc and depending on which team/department you work in it can be a very supportive and rewarding place to work. Lots of opportunities to join entry level roles without meeting the full criteria, and good pay/benefits.
CEO is an inspirational leader and genuinely wants to make a difference.
cons:
I would echo the "if your face fits" comments, career progression only comes to those who are 'in' with the right people. Poor performance is not dealt with, good performance is not recognised and no development / training is given.
The people with most power are those who shout the loudest, rules do not apply for these people and whatever they say goes. This has created a toxic atmosphere which is a severe drain on mental health, there are many good employees trying to keep the services going despite these people. There is so much unrecognised potential.
There is no room for upwards challenge here and there is bullying / harassment within most departments which has caused a lot of good employees to leave without securing their next employment.

review_title: Avoid at all costs for the sake of your health and sanity!
pros:
Close to where I lived, seemed like a nice place at the start of my employment there. 
There are some genuinely nice people that work here.
cons:
Where to begin: 
Like I said at the start it seemed like the “great place to work” that it promotes itself as, but you soon get to see the bullying, cliques, underhand and unprofessional people and lack of adhering to their own policies. 
All of the previous posters who mentioned “if your face fits” are completely correct, it’s all about who you know instead of skill based, or right person for the job. Same with regards to the fake posts from employees, I know someone who was asked to write a positive post on here by their manager after they had won a Star Award. 
If you value your career & have any self respect avoid this place like the plague. 
I genuinely didn’t know how miserable I’d been until about 6 weeks after I left and the fog lifted.  It wears you down to the point you just accept the culture, because management don’t want / aren’t interested in change unless it benefits them.

job_title: Customer Liaison Officer in Lancaster, England
pros: Career progression, supporting management team and staff.
cons: No cons to state. Great place to work

job_title: Customer Accounts Advisor in Oldham, England
pros: Only good thing is the pay, but there's no pay progression for showing good work.
cons: A lot of discrimination and not a lot of equality within the Customer Accounts team. People who want to excel are pushed back down 'into their place'.

review_title: Massively rewarding and invested in their employees
pros:
Great D&I work
Training and development
Job fulfilment 
Rewarding
Open to change and quick to respond to improve
Great team moral
cons: It can be challenging to change and improve as is a charity and a lot of funding from local councils

pros:
Been here for 9 months so far. Changed from retail to care during covid. Wish I had done it years ago!

Healthcare, flexible hours, good training.
cons: Pay isn’t great but that’s just care!

pros: Excellent hours. Lots of support when you need it and good communication all round.
cons: None at all to be fair.

pros: Good benefits and holiday allowance
cons: Bad attitude of Senior Management

pros: Good salary and great benefits
cons: Can be very cliquey at times.

pros: good manager to work for
cons: sometimes unrealistic aims and wants

pros: Not a bad place to work
cons:
So many underlying issues
Work not being completed 
Pressure on staff

review_title: Negative,  dead end and a bad blame culture. I had been shouted at and berated in meetings for doing my job correctly
pros:
The pay
Some decent people do work here
cons:
Senior management 
Advantages for friends of high ups
Negative atmosphere 
No progression/ dead end career 
The fact that I feel so much healthier now that I am away from that work environment is a damning indictment of the department

pros: just the customers, some lovely carers
cons: where to begin! being constantly hassled to do more hours, expected to work 15 hours a day witha 2 hour break in the middle. mileage paid as the crow flies!!! seriously! so end up paying loads of petrol out of pocket. only get paid for contact hours with customer so due to bad rotas sitting about in car not getting paid. dont get paid when need to go to office to get ppe, etc, no petrol given either, lots of gossiping staff

pros: Rewarding long service, flexibility with appointments and hours, good leadership team, great network of people
cons: Some areas can be cliquey but that's the same with any business

review_title: Great company - Never a bad day
job_title: Customer Service Manager in Crewe, England
pros: Really care about staff throughout CV19. Promote from within and want to offer ongoing training for your role. Management above me are supportive and always have time to listen to you. The Director in Customer Service is just superb, always has 5 minutes for you when you used to bump into him.
cons: Can take a while to put improvements in place. But once in, full support to get things rolling and working right

job_title: Customer Experience Designer in London, England
pros:
Guinness are currently moving at pace through an exciting and innovative change programme. They're involving colleagues and customers in their future state designs and are trying hard to create an environment that energises colleagues and delivers the services that customers really want, and how they want.   

Having worked at Guinness since 2009, I've seen us move through many change programmes...this is the first time I've really felt invested in the changes, and feel as though we're onto something special.
cons:
As with any change, it doesn't always run smoothly and this is no exception...it's been a difficult and challenging time over the last year for many colleagues. We've lost some fantastic talent through the changes, but this is inevitable with change of this scope. On the flip side, we have also gained and retained some incredible people. 

I can only assume it is these changes that have lead to the negative comments about Guinness, as I for one, am an employee that feels proud of who we are, what we've achieved and what is yet to come.

job_title: Business Administrator in Portsmouth, Isle of Wight, South East England, England
pros: Great support from the team
cons: ot much space to progress

job_title: P2P Finance Assistant in Manchester, England
pros:
People - COT North team - approachable, good atmosphere 
Location - easy to reach via motorway or tram
In-house canteen - fresh food, affordable and delicious
cons: Not much to do during the lunch break - no shops nearby, just a pub and takeaways.

job_title: Desktop Support Technician in Manchester, England
pros:
Found all the staff professional, friendly and helpful lot's of training.

CEO is a babe.
cons: Nothing, really miss working there, made a lot of friends in different offices.

job_title: Housing Support Officer in Manchester, England
pros: Struggling to think of any, it pays the bills, but there are probably better ways of doing it.
cons:
1. Shocking management, barely any of them have any experience of the job they are supposed to be managing, leading to unrealistic expectations and a MESS. Ridiculous layers of unnecessary management, taking up big wages which for a company obsessed with value for money, is a little strange.

2. If said unrealistic expectations are not met you are met with the brown envelope, a dreaded disciplinary, called into a hearing in a degrading manner, purely to save the company paying out performance bonuses and to keep you 'in line'.

3. For a company that has it's own dictionary of 'Guinness words', one being value for money, they have absolutely no idea on the subject, constantly talking about 'amazing service' which they cannot provide. Because of this they will always listen to the customer ahead of their own staff, even if the customer is wrong, and yes the customer can be wrong!

4. It is like North Korea, staff told not to say anything negative about the organisation to customers or friends, to constantly smile and tell them how amazing the service is ect, but do not tell them the truth. This is typified on here as the positive reviews are all written by the top managers to counter the low star rating the company has thoroughly deserved, none of them are from the staff that's for sure. BRUTAL DICTATORSHIP.

review_title: A great company to work for
pros: Guinness cares about its staff
cons: There are no negatives to report

pros: Good, competitive rates of pay
cons: None that I can think of.

pros:
I've worked at Guinness for 18 months so I am not privy to the experiences that some of the more senior staff have, but as a "fresh" employee I can honestly say that I have been enjoying my time at Guinness. The staff have ALL been professional and pleasant with me and I believe that if you get on with the work that you are meant to be doing then it is recognised and respected.  People who come on here and whine about the Company have obviously had a different experience that I have had and am having. 
Its not bad money for the work you do. 
They make sure H&S is a priority when asking you to carry out tasks and will provide you with clothing and equipment.
The holidays are decent at 25 days per year.
I could go on.
All in all I AM HAPPY working at Guinness.
cons:
Too much whining by staff who Dont appreciate how cushy they have it.
Good staff just need to start to believe more that their efforts are appreciated.
Customers of Guinness too quick to criticise and Dont have the same incentive to praise.

pros: There are some fantastic staff, really hard workers and people who genuinely care about doing a good job.    Salaries in my area are fair, good benefits and holiday entitlement.
cons: The pace of change at this company is too fast.  Upper management have completely unrealistic expectations of their staff and expect to get whatever they want at breakneck speed.  Project based staff are treated completely differently to normal employees and are expected to put the projects before everything else even leave and training.   Quantity is considered more important than quality and the focus is on how fast things can happen rather than doing it well.  The company is littered with external consultants while in other areas there are vacancies that aren't allowed to be filled.  This is not a great place to work, which is such a shame because it really used to be.  The CEO is not the person named below or the review for that would be less.

pros: I really do struggle to say anything positive about my time at Guinness , it is well known in the Housing association industry that Guinness is a poor provider & employer . It is a shame i had to learn this first hand , the culture is bad & that reflects on every day working & unfortunately its the tenants that suffer the most   , sticking plasters on open wounds is never the answer to problems . The senior management are not interested in their tenants or the industry , they want to ride the wave of power & influence , networking to other non jobs with the same benefits. I joined to help & improve lives & hopefully make a difference but i soon learned that this is never going to be tolerated or encouraged.
cons: See above , i could not do my job in a humane manner , show empathy or concern as it was seen as a weakness . The whole company is poor & needs a shake up from the top down.

review_title: The most professional and employee orientated place I have come across
job_title: Complaints and Quality Advisor in Oldham, England
pros:
One of the highest paid salaries within it's business sector.
Great opportunities to move into different departments and excel your career.
Great management.
High calibre of employees - Most customer service facing roles are happy to employ anybody to fill the role. Guinness have an extremely thorough interview process and only employ the best. It's very refreshing to get to work with colleagues who are professional and helpful.
The company is like one big family.
You are paid full wage if you are off sick. They are extremely understanding and flexible when it comes to being off.
Senior management are very approachable and friendly.
There is flexibility in your work and social life. If I need a day off, I get it.
cons: As this is a customer service environment, you can get some extremely difficult customers on the other end of the phone. They may end up shouting and swearing, however, you are allowed to terminate the call if this does happen.

review_title: Staff are just a number and not appreciated
job_title: Housing Officer in Newport Pagnell, England
pros: Good Pay, Extra days holiday at Christmas, 35 hour week, Some great staff in different teams who really give 100%
cons: Constant restructuring makes jobs unsecure (3 restructures for the same team in 5 years) staff are not valued for all the hard work that they do, good staff are not praised however staff that sit on there phones all day not completing work correctly are not brought up on it. relocating teams to different offices losing all the experience of the current workers and employing people at a high level with no knowledge of the industry, if you find out that you are being made redundant you are left alone to complete your notice and not supported through the difficult time which again makes you feel unappreciated and just a number. No flexi time anymore so if you work longer hours you can not take it off another time.

pros: Lovely residents, that’s about it
cons: Poor management, not giving contracted hours staff very clicky bullies avoid

pros: I have been employed at Guinness for 3 years and there has been a lot of change with more to come. This is necessary change and not just for the sake of it. The housing sector is changing  - there are less grants to build and regenerate homes and benefit reforms are changing how our customers manage their money.   I love working for an organisation with social purpose. I work with great colleagues in a modern and well equipped office.  The benefits package is very good with good leave entitlement, pension, a degree of flexibility and other staff benefits. I feel that I am part of the future of an evolving Guinness.
cons:
It's not perfect! What job is? sometimes there is poor communication between senior management and staff - although they are trying to improve this.
The IT is not as good as it should be and it can be frustrating.
it does feel sometimes that we are governed by outdated rules and procedures.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Milton Keynes, England
pros:
During my time at Guinness I worked with some great people and was able to take advantage of a range of excellent training opportunities. The experience has certainly helped to develop my career. 

Worked as part of a fantastic team
Salary/benefits
Plenty of opportunities for progression and to get involved in various projects
Lots of great training
Office is modern and in a great location
There are a lot of great people in the wider business who are always happy to offer help and advice
Standard 9-5 Monday - Friday
cons:
Communication between teams still needs to be improved
There seems to be a lack of consequences for under performing  staff within certain teams
Software really needs updating

pros: I will never work for GP again
cons: GP rewarded my loyalty to them after 17 years by reducing my salary by 25%, taking away the company car, and TUPE transferring me and my team into another completely inappropriate part of the group (which im told they have reversed back again now).They also reduced the salary of 2 members of the team I managed, both of whom were in low paid roles. The effect that this had on all of us was extremely  distressing. It felt like punishment, and led to me putting my housing career on hold for a while as I was so disillusioned at the end of it all. As a result now of my own hard work and tenacity  I have turned this round and am back in a role that I'm really enjoying and working for a good employer. No thanks to Guinness who treated me like a dog with no regard for mine or my teams wellbeing or the damaging impact on all of us of their overriding  obsession with their precious profits , regardless of their staffs wellbeing. Beware if you are considering a job with them. I will never forget what they did to me and my team and nothing would make it worth ever working for them again.

pros: The culture of Guinness is great and everyone I worked with is amazing. I had a real chance to further my career and Guinness has opened many doors for me. I love that customers are at the heart of Guinness and everything they do. I was constantly given constructive feedback from my manager which helped me self improve and progress, I was always recognised for going above and beyond and made aware of new opportunities. Guinness have really good training opportunities, I went on many courses which not only helped me at Guinness, it helped me further my career beyond Guinness.
cons: Work load is high, you need to be hard-working and dedicated to succeed at Guinness.

job_title: Estates Service Officer in London, England
pros: I agree with all of the comments above good pay good benefits good  hours
cons: Also agree with all of the above comments it's great to see my feeling confirmed. They have  no clear vision during my time there had 7 managers in 2 years says sums it up it all poor middle management mates appointed to job not who is qualified for the job or at least shows aptitude for the job more interested in what other managers think than doing a great job and unwilling to praise when employees do well . Clueless HR inconsistent on there own policies don't stick to lack of empathy.   Poor systems in place slow slow! , no follow through poor communication among all departments  incompetence or lack of taking pride in work really and truly not a great place to work or live according to tenants. So much more I could say...

review_title: Have you paid people to put positive reviews?
pros: Very little ok money but money certainly isn't everything
cons: This organisation has completely forgotten what it does, provide social housing. The contempt for customers is astounding. There is no heart or soul in this business. It's about money and it's ran by accountants with no idea how customers live or the services that are provided. It's far too corporate, with far too many Directors and absolutely useless heads of service. How many Project Managers does a housing association actually need? Then it's constant change. It's not the staffs fault that the executive team cannot get anything right that they then have to make another change it's quite unbelievable. There is no open culture. In some services they are run in the most unprofessional ways - boozing with their favourites, treating those whose face doesn't fit with utter contempt. And this is continuously allowed to happen. Sometimes it's like working in a playground.

pros: travel is given within your contacted hrs but to be honest it needs to be as the size of the company and area it covers. if I set of early to miss traffic I can take the time back at the end of the day so I get home early, this benefits everyone. pay is good one of the best for public sector housing.
cons: some managers have no trade back ground this means they try to implement stuff that everyone but them knows will not work. my manager is under a lot of pressure but don't pass it down on to his team other managers are not the same and the teams aren't happy.

review_title: Shambles get out while you can
pros: Are gradually bieng eroded,untill theres none
cons:
The problems are all in senior management,WOW where to start,they make awfull decisions but use other peoples money,they promise a brighter future but CAN NOT deliver,year on year.
Some decisions are terminal,for all concerned,and yet the most senior managers fail to accept their mistakes or implement a course of change,they are never wrong.
Those responsible are normally rewarded with decent jobs within other departments of the company and yet decent,hardworking  honest staff are disciplined,in a company that LOVES to discipline its staff.
Most days you feel ashamed to represent a company that does so little to address its customers needs,too many senior managers have been too cosy for too long with a failing board going in the wrong direction.
This company is a pale shadow of the Northern counties days,its a car crash waiting to happen,you work here at your peril,its a shambles

pros: Free Parking, great colleagues, nice office. Flexible hours for some. Good pay.
cons: When I first joined TGP over 4 years ago, I thought I was joining a forward thinking company that treated its staff well. In the last 2 years especially I have seen a dramatic decline. Flexitime stripped away, other good t&cs to follow no doubt. I have witnessed so many people abuse the system whilst others who work hard are thought of no better. The place is losing knowledge and great people at an alarming rate. Replaced by inexperienced and much lazier staff as echoed in other posts. The higher management seem clueless and literally don't know what we do on the frontline! Restructure after restructure, their is no job security. The remaining staff are showing a complete lack of confidence. Most systems aren't fit for purpose and historical data is almost impossible to find. Departments seem to take joy in fighting with each other. Customers are been ripped off paying more for services they can no longer get.

review_title: Terrible place to work - don't believe the positive reviews there written by exec team
pros: Some excellent staff. Nice buildings. Salaries.
cons: There are so many it's hard to know where to start.  Undertaking a ruthless culling of staff following a review by KPMG Boxwood who have absolutely no understanding of housing.  The best staff are being disposed of and replaced by completely inexperienced people who don't know what they're doing and aren't being supported.  I expect they're cheaper to employ. It's easy to be tempted by the higher than average salaries but the amount of work you'll be expected to do, will leave you stressed, demoralised and un-appreciated.  Having moved to another housing association at a slightly lower salary, I can't believe the difference in how they treat their staff. The shortfall in pay is more than compensated by being treated decently.  I wouldn't work here again if they tripled the salary.

job_title: Support Worker in Portsmouth, Isle of Wight, South East England, England
pros:
Reasonable pay  and holiday allowance 
No Micromanagement 
Good Team 
Good Job Satisfaction 
Good Support From Line Manager 
Good Work/Life Balance
cons:
•	Lack of Career Progression Opportunities 
•	Lack of Communication  from senior management with regard to our specific 
          teams longer term goals and  funding 
•	Lack of good quality relevant  training . We undertake free training made available by the local council and generic care work training , although we do not carry out personal care.

review_title: Worst company I ever worked for
pros: Nice group of fellow team members. Decent enough pay for what we actually did and if your face fits you have a good chance of promotion.
cons:
The company is forgetting that it is social housing and that they are dealing with tenants who have support needs. The focus is purely on collecting money as though they were private landlords and advisors are pitted against each other to collect the most money by playing games. The well-being of the tenant is a complete after thought. 
Staff are left feeling over worked, under appreciated and demotivated. Morale is extremely low, I didn't know anyone happy in their job ( apart from management level). They don't Care if experienced staff leave as they can then get staff in who don't know the old values of Guinness and who will work purely as a telephone debt collection agency.

job_title: Regional Manager in Milton Keynes, England
pros: The Company has a clear set of values and objectives that are clearly communicated to all levels of the organisation and the Executive Team ensure they are visible. This means that I am very clear about what I am expected to do and the standards required of me together with regular reviews and support to achieve my own objectives. In terms of the overall benefits of working for The Guinness Partnership it has excellent terms and conditions, for which employees are rightly expected to work hard and give full commitment to their role.
cons: Being a large widely geographically dispersed organisation you can feel remote from the decision making process. This can then lead to a lack of understanding of the rationale behind decisions.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Milton Keynes, England
pros:
The progression can be good, the training they offer and qualifications. 
I was able to complete a number of qualifications during my time with the company and although not supported with any study leave the funding of the courses was great. 
They also offer £100 a year towards non work related courses which is great!
cons:
Can be top heavy and alot of power at the top. Middle management can get the brunt but thats all part of the job you choose, like anywhere! 
Changing all the time, some positive but others leave you scratching your head abit. People leave due to lack of security in their job which is a shame when you enjoy what you do.

review_title: TGP review - brilliant place to work.
job_title: Complaints and Quality Advisor in Oldham, England
pros: TGP is a great place to work, the company has plenty of scope for internal progression and managers really support you to achieve this. I have worked here for 5 years and have always been supported in my role as both a Customer Service Advisor and a Complaint and Quality Advisor.  There are plenty of chances for secondments so employees can work in different departments and gain valuable knowledge working within different teams. The company puts customers first and is constantly trying to improve the customer experience.
cons: There has recently been a lot of big changes within the partnership which have taken some getting used to.  However, these have all been to benefit staff and our customers. Management have been very supportive in helping staff to adjust to the changes.

review_title: Really care about and look after their staff
pros: I have worked at Guinness for over 9 years and the past few months have really shown how much they care for their staff. We have all been paid in full, kept up to date with a wealth of information on CV on a dedicated intranet page and had weekly emails from our CEO. We have also all be sent face masks to keep us safe even if we're home based during the pandemic. The way the handled the pandemic has been exemplary and I feel very lucky to be employed by them.
cons: Experts aren't trusted in their fields and everything needs sign-off at a very senior level which slows things down. Career progression can be limited in some roles despite over acheving consistently.

pros:
Everybody mentions the free tea and coffee, so maybe that's about it.
Pros included being privileged to work alongside staff who genuinely cared and displayed loyalty and commitment throughout very difficult times.
cons: The powers that be could be likened to The Borg from Star Trek "resistance is futile"!  Couldn't be further away from the great Richard Branson's advice of "train your staff well enough so they can leave and treat them well enough to make them want to stay". If you are innovative, loyal and wish to give your best to make a difference in the housing sector; look elsewhere in the galaxy.

pros: Hi, Having come from a long terms civil service background and working for this organisation,opened my eyes to the real world.  TGP is great place to work subject to the the extreme informality relationships and favoritism widespread within managers and staff members.  If it want for this and there non-openness to change in the company,  I wouldn't be looking for another job.
cons: There management have made draconian changes already in the last 12 months, which i wish was mentioned in the job interview (I joined 05/2016 for work/life balance).  There have been offices losing down and redundancies.  There will be further business workforce and asset reductions.

pros:
Good rates of pay 
Work with some great colleagues 
Good employee benefits
Could be rewarding/satisfying  job with the right people in charge
cons:
No direction whatsoever, nobody seems to have a clue how to solve basic everyday problems. Lots of meetings, lots of emails, lots of walking about, lots of staring at computer screens but no end product.  In  fact the only problems managers solve with any concerted effort are the ones they create themselves, usually involving disciplinary procedures for some poor sod below them to deflect blame. 

Far too many people in charge resulting in a chaotic atmosphere 

Way too many unnecessary processes brings everything to a grinding halt

Winners and losers within depending on which department you work in, nothing is equal at Guinness

pros:
Provides great opportunities.
Clear social purpose.
Great pay and conditions.
Firm plans for dealing with a changing environment.
Allows staff autonomy to deliver their objectives.
If you speak up in the right way you will be listened to! 
Really cares about the wellbeing of our customers.
cons:
Change is sometimes managed in a chaotic way.
Seem very focused on centralising services which were delivered better locally.
Some managers create silos and within these they then bully and undermine capable colleagues.
IT systems are pretty basic
Processes make service improvement harder then it needs to be.
Lots of negative staff plodding along bringing others down.

pros:
Fantastic place to work with really friendly people. 
The company is really keen to make things better for its people - both employees and customers alike.
It's really open to new ideas, change and innovation, and keep true to its historical roots, even in the face of an evolving Housing Sector.
cons: It has gone through a lot of large scale changes over the last few years. However, coming into the company at the tail-end of these changes, the positive effect of these changes can really be seen.

review_title: Huge amount of change that the leadership team do not know how to deal with....train crash waiting to happen!!
pros:
Pay and benefits - salaries above market rate
Some great people and colleagues
Location and parking 
Offices in good condition  on site canteen....with free tea and coffee
cons:
Change management rubbish.....too much of a blame culture.
Exec team not diverse enough or commercial enough to deal with current issues
Very reactive......hierarchical ....No PLAN in place to deal with crisis.....
Good people leaving....
Very rapidly becoming the worst place to work...

pros: Guinness is the type of company that supports its staff to be the best they can be, and encourages new ways of working. The development opportunities I've experienced since working here are second to none.
cons: It's safe to say there's been a lot of change over the last few years which has been unsettling for a lot of staff.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Milton Keynes, England
pros: The place has still managed to retain some staff who have great intentions and genuinely want to help people, these people are mostly in front line services such as housing officers or surveyors but will generally be trampled on by management a few levels above for anything they do.
cons: Blame culture, expect hundreds of emails a day as everyone cc's everyone to cover their own backs, achieving KPIs at any cost- I.e working against other teams and the expectation that officers should work in their own time whenever necessary.

review_title: When one star is too many
job_title: Chief Scapegoat and Head Whipping Boy in Oldham, England
pros: None - you'd better believe it. There's nothing good about this horrible place
cons: Too many to list. Managers are bullies and their managers are even bigger bullies. My manager seems to resent the fact that I take the lunch break that I am legally enitled to. There seems to be an expectation that you should work extra hours for no extra pay which is modern day slavery.  Little work is planned - you get given work and not time to complete it then given more and more work then you get critisised if you go home with work unfinished even when you have stayed well beyond when you should have left.

review_title: Not a nice company to work for, inflexible and heirachical
pros: good benefits, offices ok although very stark
cons: What they sell you at interview is not who they are. Company is from the dark ages in the way they treat staff and how inconsistent they are. Company is going through alot of change and that is the excuse we keep being told but that isnt relevant. They say they offer flexible working  they dont, just to the select few it very much depends on who your manager is. They don't trust their staff to manage their time. 5th and 4th floor in London is like a morgue. You are not allowed to talk to people as it 'disturbs' the directors. Cold unpleasant place to work

pros: A lot of encouragement from management to succeed and progress where possible. Great staff benefits for health care and money towards learning a new skill. Friendly staff who are passionate about what they do and delivering great customer service. Moving to a new digital era and promoting easy access to information for customers
cons: A lot of change however this has produced some great teams and streamlined processes. Remember to keep people updated. More partnership opportunities for teams to meet

pros:
I consider myself a very enthusiastic, hard working individual with a positive can do attitude.

I am afraid I have nothing positive to say about this terribly led organisation.
cons:
I've worked at Guinness Partnership for over two years and I'be seen the organisation go from OK to awful.

The morale is low, management are rude to staff and senior management are never seen throughout the business.

Local offices have been closed to customers' and are poorly maintained.  

IT systems are very poor which leads to an extremely inefficient, poor service being offered to our customers.

The organisation is run by those who do not have the necessary business acumen to look after our customers.



I

pros:
Evolving and strong housing provider with strong leadership
Excellent training and development opportunities 
Great place to work - lots of talented decent people who care
Employees have the opportunity to influence change
Leadership acts on customer and employee feedback
Genuine focus on improving customer service 
Flexible work environment 
Progressive, challenging, high volume of work but it's always interesting
cons: Processes can be bureaucratic but there is real commitment from Leadership Team to eliminate these.

pros: Very Supportive of Career Development, Plenty of Training on offer, Some very knowledgeable staff
cons: No golden thread which brings the organisation forward as one. Over reliance on consultants and poor project management. Too much silo working and politics, with a lot of knowledge leaving the organisation. One sized fits all approach doesn't work.

pros: Majority of staff are really good. They work as teams. Benefits are good. On site deli which is a bonus and free parking
cons: Certain staff take advantage and HR let them. Things only get done if your managers face fits. Good hard working and knowledgeable staff are overlooked and discarded.

pros: Large organisation undertaking major transformation to improve services. Exciting changes with great development opportunities for staff involved in the design of this.  New efficient processes being designed to help people do their jobs, removing duplication and barriers to good customer service.
cons: Major change resulting in loss of good staff with knowledge about the company, and customers.   Big change takes a long time to embed .

pros: I have been at Guinness almost 2 years and feel it is a great place to work. Management are very supportive and you have the chance to progress within the company. The staff are all extremely friendly and helpful.
cons: There have been lots of changes recently which has caused a bit of confusion but management have been very supportive during this time

review_title: Looks like HR's been busy faking reviews(!)
pros: Salary and at one point the people
cons: Where to start? Firstly the low reviews are all true, I worked for TGP (as its now known) for 3 and a half years and it started off as the best job I ever had with some of the best people I've ever worked with but my did that change quickly. All of TGP's issues are down to the changing of the CEO and constant changes in my opinion, Ms Simmons probably wanted to leave a lasting impression after she took over and she certainly achieved it. I'm not sure if her vision was one of an organisation that is criminally incompetent, festers and harbours bullying and intimidation and devoid of any decency but that's exactly whats been achieved. Before HR come back to me with their generic and meaningless response about 'how sorry they are to hear this', let me just say that I have no grudges and nothing to gain but you are also part of the problem. I left the organisation as I came to the conclusion that I valued my time, principles and sanity above the supposed security of a job, I was constantly fixing mistakes made by people and got no thanks for it, in fact quite the opposite. There's a cliquishness across the organisation and if you're not in it you'll soon know. I thankfully found a role with an organisation that not only cares about its employees but also the people they serve. There IS a culture of bullying whether you want to admit it or not and a collection of some of the most useless and incompetent people I've ever had the misfortune to work with. The constant changes and restructures - which happen about every 12 months - has resulted in TGP losing its best and brightest replacing them with worst of the worst. Some of the brown nosing in the organisation is nauseating and unfortunately its those people that get ahead - you only need to look at the reviews from the employees who have willingly put in their job titles and given it a 5 star rating. I think the worst thing however is how they treat their tenants and occupants, again you only need to google the Guinness partnership and click the news tab to see how many times they've made the news across the country. I probably wouldn't have gone out of my way to write this review if the company was making some inroads, they constantly bang on about saving money and the need for change but the amount of money  they are haemorrhaging is unbelievable. Looking at them you'd never think they were a provider of social housing as they act more like a banking corporation but that's exactly what they're trying to model themselves as. I could go on and on but suffice to say its an organisation best avoided.

pros:
* nice people 
* good selection of offices across the UK (London, Bristol, Milton Keynes, Oldham etc.) 
* good selection of roles
cons:
* some employees are absolute deadwood and the company is not really a meritocracy 
* high levels of job instability (i.e. a lot of redundancies and "transitions") 
* big difference in pay and treatment between different employees 
* stupid/sometimes enraging policies and financial management
* focus on customers and not employees

review_title: Great pay but no career progression!
job_title: Infrastructure and Desktop Analyst in Oldham, England
pros: Great pay, great benefits, great transport links near Oldham office, great staff, great working environment.
cons: No career progression, communication between team is not good in IT services. Helpdesk staff are not updated on what is going on in IT services some of the time. Better communication is required.

review_title: OK role just not a place to stay with
pros:
Lovely office space at Oldham
The positive people even some going through big changes 
Good training opportunities
cons:
Controlled culture by senior management
Not enough parking for staff
Expectations to work very long hours

pros: None at all, nothing positive to say about this god awful organisation. Bad manager, bad wages, bad work conditions, all round bad bad bad!!
cons:
Manager was a bully, didn’t like staff having own opinion.
Talked about a training method where a plastic frog was clicked to remind staff to say key words when answering the phone-I likened it to clicker training for dogs and staff agreed, without batting an eyelid that dog training methods were not suitable for staff!
I didn’t fit with her ideal of staff member and she gunned for me until I was dismissed.

review_title: Dead end work, no progression, glossy brochure full of false,fake promises.
pros: Some genuinely nice people work here in customer facing(not telephone talking-I mean door knocking,home visiting,ground walking and tool using  people)who deserve so much more than they are ever credited for.
cons:
No progression- once in a role,that's it. Not a career job,it's dead end stuff.
Endless  data collection designed to be used against staff during the numerous and frequent job cuts.
Face fits type environment- don't bother having opinions-they mean nothing unless you are higher management.
"Customers" can be as asbusive and obnoxious as they want with little or no comebacks from Guinness-but woe betide the staff member who gets annoyed and says anything back to a customer that doesn't end with a please or thank you or suggests anything negative. A customer can dump his rubbish where he wants and get it moved for nothing,can break things in his home on purpose and get it fixed freely with an apology and compensation from this company- he can be racist,sexist,violent,ignorant and arrogant as he likes knowing Guinness will do nothing except offer him help.
Prepare to be thought of as a nobody,a nothing and less- you are nothing more here than a name on someone KPI data sheets- the glossy brochure promises a team,a family,a happy smiley environment where you count- it's quite the opposite- you are tracked,monitored and audited at every angle with the management telling you it's to ensure best possible workmanship- this is rubbish. The data collated is to score you ready for future redundancies-recently proved in the repairs dept. 
Many Senior managers are vindictive and poisonous towards their own staff and others in differing areas-escalations of minor issues are frequent in order to deflect blame so their numbers look good at the end of the month.
Practically everything this company offer is fake,unobtainable or empty promises- check out the customer comments on their posts on Facebook.
Also- ask  a new employee if their job role is anything close to the advertised specs once they get the post....

pros: Nice building and the pays not too bad either. There are also a few perks like Simply Health and extra days off at Christmas
cons: Always reviewing teams so no job seems safe. The overall moral is very low and there is a general atmosphere of stress and unfriendlyness

review_title: Awful experience, haunting. Wouldn't recommend to my enemy.
pros: Pay. That's the only good thing. However for the amount of pressure and red tape in the end it's not worth it
cons: Management are bullies. Don't care about you or your job just the end result. No recognition is given to the people that have got the results. Never have a child whilst here. Management will make no effort to ensure you're ok or be flexible whatsoever with new working hours. It's all about the business and profit not about staff or customers.

pros:
I have worked for The Guinness Partnership for a few years and can honestly say that they are my employer of choice.
The culture of the Company is changing and the Guinness Behaviours are a large influence in that change.  Our behaviours install professionalism and if you embrace them it is recognised and rewarded.
cons: Government policy has a huge impact in the social housing sector.

review_title: Great organisation. Love working here and being part of the Guinness team.
pros: The culture. The people are fantastic. The leadership team and ceo care about staff. We make a difference to people who need our help with a home.
cons: Nothing. I love it here

job_title: Real Estate Assistant in Brighton, England
pros: Good team at entry level. Good varied work on multiple sites.Good working hours and days with a good rate of pay.
cons: Poor team at management level, full of cliques and you'll only get on if your face fits. Want yes people who can't think for themselves, don't like individuals or personality. They are unfair in the way they treat their staff depending on whether your face fits or not.

pros: Good benefits, generally friendly staff
cons: Company is very confused, no clear leadership, poor communication. People being brought in at the top with no knowledge of job roles beneath them

review_title: Take advice from myself and so many others don't work here

cons:
Favouritism cliques unprofessional AMAZING  not!!!!

management, oppressive practice, likes yes people, you need to be a robot lack of training bad communication do as I say not as I do. Instead of training a warning in your file. What a truly AMAZING place.

job_title: Customer Account Advisor in Oldham, England
pros: I cannot think of one positive to say about this department
cons: If your face fits your ok. God help you if they dislike you, or you ever speak up or you ever say anything management don’t like. The atmosphere is awful and now you know the real reason why they advertise constantly - this is a job I will never forget and that’s not in a good way

review_title: A Good company struggling with its identity

job_title: Assistant Housing Officer in Chesterfield, England
pros: Flexible working excellent salary but the company takes away all your confidence
cons: Worst company I have worked for. If you are a yes person then you will be ok but whatever you do do not challenge. Just go with the flow. Managers bullies and have their favourites. Does not reward hard work  If you are lazy you will definitely get on. AVOID this company for your own sanity.

pros: Lovely colleagues, good salary, had worked for many years for Guinness who used to be a great company who looked after their staff.
cons: After the merger into the Guinness partnership it all went down the pan.  Massive change of management closure f offices, change for change sake. Staff demoralised and bullied. Consultants constantly in and the tenants came bottom of the list.  From a great place to work to a truly terrible one.

review_title: If your face doesn't fit your bullied out
job_title: Customer Service Advisor in Oldham, England

cons: Management are bullies and gossips. If one takes a disliking to you you may as well leave because they will get you out.

pros: Free Parking and Partnership Days
cons: We are always being told that communication is key and yet there is a serious lack of communication from the top downwards. External consultants are making decisions on something they know nothing about. The top echelons should be looking at what is happening on the ground, not burying their heads in the clouds.

review_title: There is a reason for the bad reviews!!
pros: Good location, company benefits and holiday entitlement
cons: Very poor and deluded management. They have no idea how the real world works. Very cliquey and if your face doesn't fit with the management team you have no chance. Ruthless tactics from management and quite a bent HR team who are no doubt bullied into agreement with management some of their underhand tactics are actually in terms with thier policies and workplace laws.

pros:

Nice Offices
CEO is good
